name: Einstein's Field Equations
description: The fundamental equations of general relativity relating spacetime curvature (left side) to the distribution of mass and energy (right side). Rμν is the Ricci curvature tensor, gμν is the metric tensor, R is the curvature scalar, and Tμν is the energy-momentum tensor

name: Schwarzschild Metric
description: The metric describing spacetime in the vacuum region surrounding a spherically symmetric, non-rotating mass M. This is the first exact solution to Einstein's field equations

name: Schwarzschild Radius
description: The radius at which the Schwarzschild metric becomes singular, defining the event horizon of a non-rotating black hole. For objects denser than this radius, escape requires speeds greater than c

name: Escape Energy Condition
description: The condition for an object of mass m to escape from the gravitational influence of a body of mass M and radius R: kinetic energy must equal gravitational potential energy

name: Escape Speed
description: The minimum speed required for an object to escape from the gravitational field of a spherical body of mass M and radius R

name: Proper Time to Singularity
description: The proper time interval for a body following a radial path to travel from the event horizon to the central singularity of a black hole

name: Light Travel Time in Schwarzschild Spacetime
description: The coordinate time interval for a photon to travel radially from r₁ to r₂ in Schwarzschild spacetime. As r₁ approaches RS, this time tends to infinity for a distant observer

name: Gravitational Redshift
description: The relationship between the frequency of light emitted at distance rem from a mass M and the frequency observed at large distance. Light escaping from near a massive object is redshifted

name: Flat Expanding Spacetime Metric
description: The metric for an expanding Universe with flat (k=0) spatial geometry, where a(t) is the scale factor and (r, θ, φ) are co-moving spherical coordinates

name: Robertson-Walker Metric
description: The general metric describing a homogeneous and isotropic expanding Universe, where a(t) is the scale factor and k is the spatial curvature parameter (k=0 flat, k>0 positive curvature, k<0 negative curvature)

name: Hubble Constant Definition
description: The Hubble constant H₀ is the present-day value of the expansion rate of the Universe, defined as the time derivative of the scale factor divided by the scale factor, evaluated at the present time t₀

name: Hubble Parameter
description: The general Hubble parameter H(t) describes the expansion rate of the Universe at any cosmic time t. A dot denotes the time derivative

name: Redshift Definition
description: The cosmological redshift z is defined in terms of the ratio of observed to emitted wavelengths (or equivalently, emitted to observed frequencies)

name: Wavefront Time Interval Relation
description: The relationship between time intervals at emission and observation for successive wavefronts of light in an expanding Universe. This is the key step in deriving the scale factor-redshift relation

name: Scale Factor-Redshift Relation
description: The fundamental relationship between the cosmic scale factor a and redshift z. The redshift of a distant galaxy tells us how much smaller the scale factor was when the light was emitted. Conventionally a(t₀)=1

name: Schwarzschild Metric (RS form)
description: The Schwarzschild metric written in terms of the Schwarzschild radius RS, useful for analyzing behavior near black holes

name: Minkowski Metric (Spherical Coordinates)
description: The flat spacetime Minkowski metric expressed in spherical coordinates. This is the limit of the Schwarzschild metric at large distances (r >> RS) from a mass
